posts.name: Vinton
posts.cooked:
Our school has a IT policy that prevents the pathplanner code file from being downloaded and prevents the code from building. I have had our other FRC team try to do it but to no avail. What we have tried: Disabling firewalls Building from a local admin account Hotspots Running .\gradlew clean I have tried it on my home computer which is a desktop and the code does build Any help would be appreciated, we leave Wednesday for a regional.

The fail message is attached as well. Screenshot 2025-03-08 160552 1397×655 32.6 KB

Screenshot 2025-03-08 160552 1397×655 32.6 KB

Screenshot 2025-03-08 160552 1397×655 32.6 KB

posts.name: Max H.
posts.cooked: Reach out to IT and ask them to disable it?

posts.name: Vinton
posts.cooked: We will, although our IT department may not get to it until after we leave.

posts.name: Pizzatc
posts.cooked: This might be a last resort but maybe have your programmer take the machine home do what needs to be done there then bring it back

posts.name: Vinton
posts.cooked: Are you referring to the laptop or the robot?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
I assume you are using a school laptop.

It’s time to switch to someone’s personal laptop until such time as the school can allow pathplanner.

posts.name: Pizzatc
posts.cooked: The laptop. Although we once did have a student take the robot home (it was still a drive train and only for 1 night)

posts.name: Vinton
posts.cooked: We have tried using the laptop on a hotspot, and it still can’t build. It seems to be a local policy that even a local admin account can’t bypass.

posts.name: Alex
Vinton
posts.cooked: Should it just replace the build.gradle file, or should I switch our code to your repo?

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: U can just add like 61 and make sure it’s in a repositories block as seen.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: Connect to a hotspot if possible. Once you download it once you won’t have to again for that computer.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
These problems are all too common for FRC teams. I’m not even a programming mentor and I routinely have issues when the school’s IT department uses cannons to kill flies. Lately I’ve had issues with them blocking SSH. Yknow, those dang kids trying to access their ec2 instances during school hours.

The only solution is to own your infra. Don’t rely on school-issued computers, and don’t rely on their network. There are plenty of cheap used laptops that will do perfectly well as a driver’s station/programming machine. Pray you have a mentor and/or student with unlimited mobile data. It’s inconvenient and dumb, but that tends to be the story with school IT.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: I would try and get a computer that is not on the schools login system. Trust me, it’s worth it if you are allowed to

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: I believe this guidance is actually echoed in the official FIRST documentation as well (at least for the Driver Station PC). They recommend a non-domain PC running basically a stock as possible.

posts.name: Vinton
posts.cooked: This did the trick, thank you!

posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked: we had the same problem I just took the laptop home built on my home network and it worked. You could also use a hotspot as well

Our school also blocks SSH for some reason–on the wifi, not computers. It’s a huge pain for me since I also need SSH to push changes to QFRCDashboard alongside robot code, so I have to open up a hotspot every single time.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Happy to hear it.  The repo syncs 2x a day so it should have all the updates as they are released

FYI, you should still be able to push changes over HTTPS. Github made it a lot more annoying requiring tokens as the password, but you can either manually create and use a personal access token , setup/use git credential manager which also comes set up by default on Git for Windows , or install the GitHub CLI which can setup authentication for you (and is what I personally use) .

link_counts.title: Managing your personal access tokens - GitHub Docs
Caching your GitHub credentials in Git - GitHub Docs
Caching your GitHub credentials in Git - GitHub Docs

accepted_answer.excerpt: You’re welcome to try our mirror, we’re mirroring a number of libraries that get blocked including path planner, choreo, MapleSim…
